updates.update_content:
It's the final countdown!!! 
Thank you all for being here!!!
Keep spreading the word!!
Quick Update 
While we've reached some of our stretch goals, Death's Diner will always be the #1 Priority.   One of the unexpected things I'm seeing after the first edit of the film, is that it will need much more VFX work and clean-up than originally budgeted. Thanks to campaign exceeding our goal, our VFX budget will be able to expand and address these VFX needs! Thank you so much for going above and beyond and supporting the film so that we can make it the best that it can be.

Final 48 Hours of the Kickstarter
A couple of updates for you: new stills, final stretch goal reached, and one last reward addition!
New Stills

updates.update_userinfo: 6 Days Left!!! Death's Diner AMA + Add-ons Reminder!
updates.update_content:
Death's Diner ends in less than 6 days!!! 
Here's a little reminder that I activated add-ons for stickers, pins, and posters!

Hey All!|

I've activated Add-On Rewards options, so now you can order as many pins, stickers, and prints as you like for yourself or friends :). I know folks were really excited about the pins so I thought this would be a nice option.

Hey all! 
To clear up some confusion I made some graphics to show what the main reward tiers are getting. 
If you pledged to a tier above these rewards, you will get everything here!

updates.update_userinfo: THANK YOU! Funded in 33 minutes! Big Update + Unlocked Stretch Goals!
updates.update_content:
Howdy Everyone and Welcome to DEATH'S DINER!
Funded in 33 Minutes and 1,000 Backers in less than 24 Hours! 
Thank you so much for being here and for supporting us in bringing DEATHS DINER to life! We are so excited and cannot believe we smashed through ALL of our Stretch Goals in just 48 hours! Of course that means lots of great updates for you. There's also additional new items from unlocked stretch goals for those interested in the physical rewards. 
New Rewards and Unlocked Stretch Goals

project_data.project_name: DEATH'S DINER: A Surreal Short Film

campaign.story:
In the hyper-fantastical bronze age megalopolis of Pentola, there is little to no distinction between artisanal and magical items; anything created with sufficient passion and skill is magical by the very nature of the world. A multitude of factions in the city seek to purchase, discover, commission, and otherwise acquire a vast collection of items to be used, investigated, or traded.
A Catalogue Chimerical is a zine of one-hundred-and-forty-four items described and illustrated by an Aydinlar Cataloguer, a specialist in analyzing and describing these fantastic objects for later use. The zine is framed as a magical mail-order catalogue. Members of their University back home acquire items by spending votive ink, the currency of the Aydinlar Suzerainty.  
Every backer of this campaign will also get a digital copy of Lost and Found, a d36 zine of Pentolan magical items! 
What's inside the zine?
Each of the thirty-six pages in this zine includes four items and at least one sketch of the items on that page. There will also be an art-free version with half the page count, ideal for printing at home.
At the base level of funding, the art edition of the zine will have one illustration for each page, meaning one quarter of the items are given custom illustrations. At higher levels of funding, additional sketches will be added until all the items are illustrated.
Here are a few examples of the writing for such items:
Thimble of Bloodsweat Endeavors - Example Item
This small porcelain thimble is chased in scarlet and has a crimson silk slip cover. The markings on the thimble itself are minute and depict a cheerful but strained proprietor hawking various wares from a cart.
If the bearer spills enough of their own blood into the thimble to fill it, they are unable to use any magic for the day, though they find all mundane ventures one step easier. Each time the thimble is used, it seems to grow in size.
Frostgiver Pendant - Example Item
This lapis lazuli pendant is miraculously strung not with wire but with thin ironoak, mysteriously supple whilst held. The engraving on the pendant shows a woman offering her cloak while snow falls thick.
Anyone whom the wearer lends clothing to finds that they are utterly immune to the cold. Until the item is returned, the pendant wearer frosts everything they touch, though their extremeties slowly become frostbitten over the next several days unless the item is returned or they give away something else.
Moonberry Ring - Example Item
This thick ring is made of smoothly polished granite and topped with an ironoak relief of the watchful moon at its zenith over a berry bush. It smells of crushed raspberries.
The bearer of this ring is compelled to kiss it and to seek out fruits to satisfy their newfound sweet tooth; every day that circumstances keep them from eating such fruit they become bitterly selfish. All tastes become extraordinarily more potent, their tongue an order of magnitude more sensitive.
Marblewound Khopesh - Example Item
This olive-handled khopesh has a Pentolan marble blade, pale green veined with gray. The hilt is polished smooth and inlaid with tiny discs of gold which hum softly unless in moonlight.
When the curved blade inflicts a wound it calcifies the damaged flesh, leaving an obvious marble scar and preventing most forms of mundane healing without further surgery.
Flamekeeper Vambraces - Example Item
These puce drakeleather vambraces are tooled meticulously in the image of roiling flames, the heart of each of them embossed with bronze.
When worn, anything held in either hand shrinks to half its normal size in a flash of scorching light, returning to normal size when let go, but glowing-hot.
Let's talk about the Art for this Zine.
The Catalogue is not just a collection of written items, however. It's also going to feature at least one illustration for every four items (36 in total!) - and, if we unlock enough stretch goals, expand all the way to ONE HUNDRED AND FORTY FOUR illustrations, one for every last item in the Catalogue.
The art will be in the form of sketches by the Cataloguer themself (Aaron Radney being the artist on Earth pulling this off), meant to be quick illustrations of the item for the readers of the Catalogue to get a visual for. Each will be roughly A9 (1.5" x 2") in size.
Aaron has an extremely well developed sketch style that was much of the inspiration for this project - when we conceived of a catalogue of magical items, it was obvious there was only one choice for who to illustrate it.
Here are a couple examples of Aaron's work in the sketch style that will be in the zine:
Alt Text: An image sketched in brown pencil on white paper of a thin, relatively androgynous figure with kinky hair sweeping back from their head, again with distinctly African features and seen from the waist up. They wear a cloak that sweeps forward sa if blone in the wind. They carry two scimitars, one in each hand and are leanly muscular wearing a wrap of some sort across their chest, loose pants and a cloth wrap around their waist with their midriff bare.
Alt Text: A picture of a male elf, seen from the shoulders up and sketched with brown and white pencil on tan toned paper. He's looking out of the corner of his eyes. He has African features, a close cropped afro and high cheekbones. The ears are long, pointed and adorned with rings. The image is lightly crosshatched for its shading.
Notes on Accessibility
Both versions of the zine will fully meet the PDF/UA Standard, ensuring that they are as accessible as we can make them. We'll also publish an epub version of the item text for easier/more accessible reading on tablets and e-readers.
We will also be producing a WCAG 2.0 Accessible website for the magical items (no art included) which will include all of the items from the zine as well as bonus items - this site will have full text search, collection pages for both bonus items and Catalogue items, and random-item selector. 
You can find a preview of that website at catalogue-chimerical.netlify.app - we'll be updating it as writing and editing is complete, putting it out as soon as they are completed so you don't need to wait on the PDFs/epub. You can actually view the bonus items right now!
Backer Tiers - what they cost and what you get for them
$1 - Curious Onlooker Tier
This tier primarily provides support to the team - every single penny and pledge helps this project be successful. You'll get a digital copy of Lost & Found, a print-at-home zine with 36 magical items in it and have access to the community copies, physical and digital alike, before anyone outside of Kickstarter gets access.
$7 - Home Scrivener Tier
In addition to prior rewards, this tier gets you a copy of the artless PDF version of Catalogue Chimerical, enabling you to print a copy at home without using all of your ink.
$12 - Chronicler Tier
In addition to prior rewards, this tier gets you a copy of the illustrated PDF edition of Catalogue Chimerical so you can revel in the beautiful art. You also make a digital community copy of both editions of the Catalogue available!
$24 - Archivist Tier
In addition to the rewards from prior tiers, at this level you get a physical copy of the illustrated PDF edition of A Catalogue Chimerical. Every 5 pledges at this level makes a physical community copy of the zine available for other folks! 
$48 - Neighborhood Advocate Tier
In addition to the rewards from the Archivist tier, at this level you fund six digital community copies instead of one and every backer at this tier funds two physical community copies as well! This tier exists for those folks who have the funds and share the belief with our team that art should be made as widely available as possible.
$72 - Artisan Tier
In addition to the rewards from the Archivist tier, at this level you also get an hour consultation with Michael on an artisan NPC - he will then go on to create a print-at-home PDF for you that includes the NPC and six items made by them, just for you! Every backer at this tier also secures both a physical and digital community copy of the Catalogue.
$144 - Dozenal Dealer Tier
This tier is primarily intended for retailers; it includes a dozen copies of the print edition of A Catalogue Chimerical and funds 12 digital and 4 physical community copies as well!
Who's on the team for A Catalogue Chimerical?
The writing for this project is by Michael T. Lombardi, the illustrations are by Aaron Radney, editing is by Samuel Mui Shen Ern, layout is by Dai Shugars, worldbuilding consultancy for the Aydinlar Suzerainty is by Bee Scerri, and character consultancy, sensitivity consultancy, and voice acting is by Persephone. Finally, if the audio format is unlocked, Adil Leghari will join the team as our audio engineer.
Aaron Radney - Illustrator
 Aaron Radney is a fantasy illustrator who loves stories, world building and how the two intersect within the field of illustration. He grew up on a steady diet of fantasy books and shows as well as a healthy dose of mythology and dragons provided by his mother’s substantial book collection. He studied at Memphis College of Art in Memphis, Tennessee and is focused both on helping clients bring their ideas to life and illuminating the power of diverse heroes through drawing heavily from non-Eurocentric inspirations. 
He’s currently based out of St. Louis Missouri living there happy with his partner and tolerating her needy tuxedo cat. In his spare time he plays fantasy card and tabletop games as well as writes to feed the world building addiction and cooks to feed his belly.
Michael T Lombardi - Writer
Michael T. Lombardi is a kitbash enthusiast game designer and developer based in in the St. Louis region of the United States. He is interested in exploring procedural generation, gameable lore, and alternative models and modes of development. He splits his free time between game and open source development (currently working on Platen, digital tooling to make hosting accessible and interactive editions of digital games easier and cheaper).
Samuel Mui Shen Ern - Editor
Samuel Mui Shen Ernis a game designer, writer, editor, musician, and visual artist from Malaysia. Their works explore real-world topics like death, relationships, and emotional brokenness with an unwaveringly brutal honesty and a sense of fun(?)! When she’s not working on hir next big thing, he’s probably zoning out to k-pop, experimenting in the kitchen, or reading autobiographical comics.
Dai Shugars - Layout Artist
Dai Shugarsis a graphic designer and publisher out of Orlando, Florida known for such books as Libreté, The Demon Collective, Lorn Song, and Mystic Punks. He's also written several articles on PDF accessibility and how RPGs could stand to better utilize the medium.
Ben "Bee" Scerri - Worldbuilding
Ben "Bee" Scerri is a non-binary bisexual Maltese Australian tabletop- and video game producer, writer, designer, and community builder, living in Melbourne, Australia. Their work focuses on themes of diaspora, disability/critical illness, self-actualisation, and found family, often through the lenses of their ethnic and queer intersections. When not writing for or about games, they're likely talking about language, cooking, baking, folklore, and/or fashion.
Persephone - Consulting & Acting
Persephone is a writer, content creator, model and sensitivity consultant working in multiple fields. She is also an active Twitch streamer, working to build a platform that promotes inclusion and acceptance.
She is also the DM of her own actual play podcast, Fast Times at D&D High, and the creator of the upcoming 5th edition parody game, Critical Love. You can find her @Persephiroth on Twitter, Twitch, TikTok, and more. 
Adil Leghari - Audio Engineer
Adil Leghari enjoys creative pursuits, playing with audio, video, and images. When not working on DevOps and Automation, he enjoys long walks on the beach, candlelit dinners, and designing stickers.
What are the stretch goals for A Catalogue Chimerical?
$8550 - Expanded Illustrations Stretch Goal
At this level, the zine will include an additional 36 (total of 72) custom illustrations by Aaron Radney, covering half of the items in the zine. 
$10,500 - Expanded Illustrations II Stretch Goal
At this level, the zine will include an additional 36 (total of 108) custom illustrations by Aaron Radney, meaning 75% of the items get an illustration.
$12000 - FULLY ILLUSTRATED Stretch Goal
At this level, the zine will include an additional 36 custom illustrations by Aaron Radney, meaning every single item in the zine will have an accompanying illustration!
$18000 - Audio Format & Diaries Stretch Goal
At this level, we will pay Persephone to read each of the entries in A Catalogue Chimerical as the Cataloguer; in-world, the document itself can carry both written word and the diction of the Cataloguer. This means that the very act of reading the Catalogue puts the voice of the Cataloguer into your head, so you hear their diction and cadence and don't have to rely on the written word alone to grasp intent and nuance.
We'll also write 12 short diary entries from the perspective of the Cataloguer, making their written form available on the website.
Adil Leghari will be editing the audio for both the diary and item entries. After the kickstarter campaign wraps (and the work is done), this audio-format for both the items and the diary will be made available separately on bandcamp! Backers at any level will have access to the digital audio if we unlock this stretch goal!
Where is the budget for A Catalogue Chimerical going?
The breakdown of funding for this project includes:
Writing and Editing ($1,440) 
36 item sketches ($900)
Layout for 54 pages [36 with art, 18 for the condensed artless version] ($840)
Worldbuilding consultancy ($1200)
Character & Sensitivity consultancy ($1800) 
A pie chart showing the budgetary breakdown for the base goal
On top of these expense items, we are including a 25% overhead/emergency fund, which includes Kickstarter's own cut. That accounts for the $7,725 initial budget.
Additional funds beyond the budget and stretch goals will be split between the team members with the writing and publishing portion of the revenue split going into the general fund for the Gondolieri Cooperative.
What is the Gondolieri Cooperative?
This project is being organized under the Gondolieri Cooperative, a new creator-owned organization under which this and all future Pentola projects are being worked. We seek to change the industry by proving out a new model which remunerates everyone involved equitably for their labor, funds the creation of art and games, and reinvests in the community both directly (supporting projects and creators, buying equipment and software, etc) and indirectly (helping keep creators housed/fed through hard times, seeding funds for creative endeavors, establishing re-usable contracts and templates). Our members are international as is the scope of our impact.
At this time, the Gondolieri Cooperative consists of three members: Pam Punzalan, Viditya Voleti, and Michael T. Lombardi.
How is digital fulfillment for A Catalogue Chimerical being handled?
After successful funding and completion of this project, backers of the project will receive access to printable PDFs of the artless and full version of the zine, as well as the epub editon, via LeanPub, where future sales of the digital copies will be available.
Additionally, access to the writing only will be available for free on catalogue-chimerical.netlify.app. That site will be updated as the project writing is completed, meaning you won't need to wait for the final shippable product to start using these items in your games.
How is physical fulfillment for A Catalogue Chimerical being handled, and by whom?
Physical fulfillment will be handled by Spear Witch in the USA, Monkey's Paw Games in Canada, and Glaucus in Australia.
Backers at a physical level will be given an at-cost coupon for the physical copy in these stores and have shipping calculated at the time that they use the coupon, meaning backers will pay for shipping via these storefronts.
This should be overall safer and cheaper for everyone, especially international folks, who won't have to absorb the international shipping costs from the USA we would otherwise have to charge.
To be abundantly clear: YOUR BACKER PLEDGE DOES NOT COVER SHIPPING. YOU WILL NEED TO PAY FOR THAT LATER VIA THE FULLFILLER STOREFRONT OF YOUR CHOICE.
What are community copies and who is getting them?
Community copies are copies of the zine which are earmarked specifically for folks who for any reason cannot afford to purchase a copy for themselves, no questions asked. We will not be means-testing submissions for community copies nor will we be checking to see if you "need" one - if you think it's for you, it is. If you don't, it probably is anyway! We do not and will not vet the claims for these copies. We trust you and the community at large to know your own situation and we absolutely encourage that these copies be claimed.
Every pledge for a copy of the zine (physical or digital) will seed a digital community copy of the PDFs as well. Every five pledges for a physical copy of the zine will seed a physical community copy as well. Every retail-level pledge will similarly seed four physical copies and twelve digital copies.
There is additionally an Advocate tier that seeds even more community copies for anyone who wants to support the community but doesn't want to buy a dozen copies for themselves.
We will be making community copies, physical and digital alike, available first to backers of this campaign, even at the $1 level, before opening them up to the wider community (assuming any copies are left).
What sort of schedule for updates can we expect during and after the campaign?
We will be posting at least daily updates to this project during the campaign (each including a draft of a new magic item) as well as point-in-time updates when we reach any relevant milestones. We will commit to biweekly updates afterward, posting a status update every other Sunday to keep you in the loop.
A note on the icons used for this campaign page
We used several CC-BY icons on this campaign page - the icons for the items came from game-icons.net while the stretch goal and backer tier icons are FontAwesome.
The FontAwesome icons were all licensed CC-BY 4.0.
The icons for the items were:
 Pouring Chalice by Lorc under CC-BY 3.0  (The Thimble of Bloodsweat Endeavors)
 Gem Chain by Lorc under CC-BY 3.0 (The Frostgiver Pendant)
 Ring by Delapouite under CC-BY 3.0 (The Moonberry Ring)
 Sparkling Saber by Lorc under CC-BY 3.0 (The Marblewound Khopesh)
 Bracer by Delapouite under CC-BY 3.0 (The Flamekeeper Vambraces)
The only changes made to any of the icons were to make them purple-and-white to fit with the colors of this campaign.
campaign.risks:
Risks and challenges
We've run kickstarters which have successfully funded and delivered before. The primary risks are of timeline - as we fund more art, the art will take longer to complete - and of physical fulfillment which is harder in 2021 than ever before. We are confident in the abilities of our fulfillment team to help us deliver physical copies if we unlock the scoped print run and in the viability of a scoped run as a risk mitigation.
Learn about accountability on Kickstarter

updates.update_content:
Hey, folks!
Just checking in to let you know consulting is under way and a new set of 20 bonus items has dropped on the website!
Here's a couple of them!
Beloved Memory Machete

Hey, folks!
Sorry I missed writing this up yesterday - was couch bound with a sick baby all weekend. They're doing okay but it took me out of pretty much everything. Good news! Kickstarter released the funds which means I get to cut a bunch of checks to folks this week and once they've got cash in hand, work can start!
This first section is going to be quiet prep work as the initial consulting on worldbuilding and character development get done, so the next several updates will likely be very short heartbeat updates just so you know we're still at it. Once we get to the "drafting more items" stage, I'll actually have more stuff to share and show!

updates.update_userinfo: 🗻 Day 14: From This Vantage Point (An Alternate Reality Post)
updates.update_content:
NB: This is an alternate reality post that I had drafted and planned to send out for when we missed our funding goal. Then, uh, we funded. Nevertheless, I hope this is amusing and useful for folks to read as it was written from the perspective of a "failed" project runner.

Hey, folks!
So: we didn't quite make it. And that's okay! Because this was an incredible campaign and I want to take a second to thank you all for every last minute of it:

Hey, folks!
So, uh, we funded in the literal final hour! What a wild, ride. I actually was drafting an update about missing funding and lessons learned from the campaign - I'm still going to post it because I think it's good and valuable, but it's just no longer true. 
We funded! And not only did we fund, we skyrocketed right past the funding and unlocked our first stretch goal, which expands the art that Aaron is going to do - fully half of the items in the Catalogue will be illustrated!!

updates.update_userinfo: BONUS UPDATE: Interview with Aaron Radney
updates.update_content:
Hey, folks!
We're twelve hours out and have one more bonus update - this time, an audio interview with Aaron Radney! I talked with Aaron last Sunday and we had waves of technical difficulties but Adil Leghari, our audio engineer, was able to salvage an awesome interview, which is below!

updates.update_userinfo: BONUS UPDATE: An Interview with Persephone!
updates.update_content:
Hey, folks! It's time for a bonus update, this one including a short written interview with Persephone!
1. Hey! Thanks for taking the time to chat with me! I thought we could start this little interview with having you talk about how you first got into tabletop and what draws you to design in this space.

Oh, I'm happy to! I'm really excited about this project, and I'm always happy to talk nerd-shop, haha.

Hey, folks!
This is it! The last of our mainline updates - everything from here will be a bonus update or post-campaign update. There remains the very real chance we won't fund - or might just fund in the last minutes - but we've still got a chance at escaping gravity here, y'all. And, in the meantime?
This project has absolutely shown the idea has some legs and, moreover, that there's interest in the physical community copies model. We have unlocked more than !

Hey folks!
We're in the last 48 hours and as of now:
222 backers have pledged $4345 bringing us 56% of the way to our goal!
We have funded 228 digital and 45 physical community copies!!
I mentioned it on Twitter, but I really want to highlight the availability of these community copies - we have more digital community copies than backers right now, which means a whole slew of folks could benefit from backing at the $1 or $7 level; with more than 40 physical community copies available, everyone stands a fairly good shot at getting one of those, even if you're cash low.

updates.update_userinfo: Day 11: 4k, 200 Backers, and the Final 72 Hours
updates.update_content:
Hey, folks!
I don't know what to say except WHOA
At the time of this writing, we've crossed over to 200 backers and more than $4,000 pledged! We're coming up on the last big push for the project to see if we can get over the line and - if we're lucky - pick up enough steam to unlock some of the expanded art, too!

project_data.project_name: A Catalogue Chimerical

campaign.story:
PRITTY - On a scorching summer day at a community pool, a black teen learns to step out of his comfort zone, and with the help of a charming neighborhood boy, overcomes his fear of the deep end. 


Savannah, GA (early 2000’s)  backdrops this naturalistic coming-of-age story. The Deep South breeds its black boys hard, then there’s JAY. He sticks out for all the wrong reasons. He’s dark-skinned, quiet and skinny; and likes to wear flowers in his hair.
The opposite of his masculine and charismatic older brother, JACOB. Their differences peak at the community pool where swaggering manhood is on full display. Jay is reserved as he struggles to embody his brother’s carefree confidence.
Until he gets help from JUSTIN, a charming, light-skinned boy from the neighborhood. Their new friendship is tested, however, when an unspoken truth dares to surface.


Terrance Daye, photographed by Alexy Kim
My name is Terrance Daye, the director of Pritty: The Animation. In 2019 I completed -Ship: A Visual Poem, an award-winning short film that significantly impacted my film career. For all of its success, however, I felt dissatisfied with filmmaking. Every day, the world seemed to grow more hateful and unjust. I asked myself, “What is the point of art-making if we’re all saying the same things and nothing is changing?”
Then I remembered a 300-page unpublished manuscript by the name of Pritty that was shared with me by a close friend and soon-to-be collaborator: Keith F. Miller, Jr. I remember being floored by the audacity of Keith’s words. His complex depiction of black men coming of age was the very hope I now needed.
There are too few stories that simply feature black boys at play, discovering their full humanity and vulnerability—and learning to heal because of it. I longed for my own work to engage more intentionally in this practice. I changed my perspective on filmmaking and committed to bringing a new question to the big screen: “What would it mean to visualize the softer, more intimate sides of black men without fear of consequence?”
With renewed vision and a devoted team by my side, I set about bringing Pritty to life. Visualizing this world and now getting to animate it has given me permission to hope again. It has been one of the highlights of my year and has taught me that filmmaking is just another form of dreaming. The world may be chaotic now. But it won’t always be. Black lives may exist on the cusp of constant peril now. But somewhere there must be joy and laughter. The media can’t imagine this for us. But we can imagine it for ourselves. Can’t we?



We originally planned to make Pritty as a live-action short film, but when our shoot got canceled due to COVID-19 we weren’t ready to give up. Through animation, we found a new way to bring Pritty to life!
Animation is a medium that is full of imagination and dreaming, and with Pritty, we are actively allowing ourselves to imagine what it looks like for black and brown boys to be free. Choosing to make animation our new medium felt like a natural fit to capture these dreams, hopes, and imaginations for our future world.
We turned to Japanese animation director, Hayao Miyazaki, to inspire the lush landscapes and naturalism that we wanted to exude through Pritty. His work became one of our largest sources of inspiration. But for all its beauty, we never saw ourselves represented in his worlds. Bring Hayao Miyazaki To The Hood became our new motto. Our hoods, our communities, our spaces with their subtleties and nuances are worthy of occupying the center. This animation is a reminder of that.
Our animation direction includes lush, romantic landscapes, textured ambient sounds, and distinctly black character designs that create a sense of immersive realism through traditional 2D Animation - an immersive Black reality that we rarely see depicted in animation.
We are partnering with Powerhouse Animation Studios in TX for our animation production. Powerhouse Animation Studios is a full-service creative agency that we are very excited to have bring our rough animatic to life and later, with your help, our full animated short! 

Character Designs from Pritty: The Animation


 Writer/Director - Terrance Daye 
Terrance Daye - Photographed by Alexey Kim & Illustration by Jarren Simmons
Terrance Daye is an award-winning poet and filmmaker from Long Island, New York. His creative work reimagines traditional representations of black masculinity and male identity and invests strongly in destigmatizing mental illness within the black community. Terrance received his Bachelor’s degree from Morehouse College and his Master’s in Fine Arts in filmmaking at NYU Tisch School of the Arts. Terrance is a two-time Spike Lee Production Fund recipient, a 2018 Sundance Ignite Fellow, the recipient of the 2020 NewFest Film Festival Emerging Black LGBTQ+ Filmmaker Award and the 2020 Outfest Film Festival Programming Award for Emerging Talent. His most recent film project -Ship: A Visual Poem was awarded a Short Film Jury Award for U.S. Fiction at the 2020 Sundance Film Festival. Terrance is currently developing his original hour-long drama, Mandingo, with the 2020 Sundance Episodic Labs. 

Executive Producer & Author of Pritty: The Novel - Keith F. Miller, Jr. 
Keith F. Miller, Jr. - Photographed by Alexey Kim & Illustration by Jarren Simmons
Keith F. Miller, Jr. is an award-winning educator, storyteller, artist-researcher, and village-builder/raiser with nearly 10 years of experience in education, spearheading youth arts, leadership, social justice, and community engagement initiatives. Additionally, he is the managing editor and creative director of The Pillow Talk Project, a rapidly growing blog and social movement dedicated to sharing the fearless stories of men--and those who love them--redefining masculinity and rediscovering the healing power of everyday intimate conversations.
Committed to supporting the healing, growth, and thriving of boys and young men of color through trauma through narrative change, creative community development, and everyday intimate conversations as activism, Keith travels the country as a National Writing Project Teaching Consultant, a National Afterschool Matters Fellow, and a Forward Promise Fellow for Leaders through the Robert Wood Johnson Foundation. He also serves as the Executive Producer for the short film, Pritty, based on his unpublished manuscript by the same name.

 Producer - Jeremy Truong 
Jeremy Truong - Photographed by Alexey Kim & Illustration by Jarren Simmons
Jeremy Truong is a San Francisco transplant working as an LGBT film producer in New York. Attracted to films with socially impactful themes, Jeremy hopes to move the needle on timely and urgent issues by exploring them in subversive ways on screen. His work has screened all over the world including the Sundance Film Festival, SXSW, BFI London, and the Tribeca Film Festival. His first feature film, ‘Cicada’ was acquired for distribution after a 2020 festival circuit and is currently in development on another feature length LGBT film. Founder of bicoastal production company, ‘rubbertape’, Jeremy is graduate of NYU’s Tisch School of the Arts and is an SFFILM Rainin Grant Recipient.

 Producer - Natalie Jasmine Harris 
Natalie Jasmine Harris - Photographed by Murugi Thande & Illustration by Jarren Simmons
Natalie Jasmine Harris is a filmmaker from Maryland.  As a producer, she is dedicated to uplifting underrepresented narratives about people of color, womxn, and LGBTQ communities. Natalie received her BFA from NYU's Tisch School of the Arts in May 2020, where she graduated with Honors and received her department's award for Excellence in Community Service. Passionate about the intersections between filmmaking and social justice, Natalie worked for Elizabeth Warren’s Presidential Campaign in 2019 as a Video Intern and recently created a short documentary in collaboration with TIME Magazine and the Biden/Harris campaign. Over the years, she has produced films that have received recognition from The Directors Guild of America, Sundance Ignite, Outfest, Vimeo Staff Pick, Short of the Week, The British Film Institute, and The National Film Festival for Talented Youth (NFFTY).


In pivoting from a live-action short film to animation, we realized that our budget would increase exponentially. However, we believe that the black kids we create this art for are worth the time, the money, and the big asks.
In this Kickstarter campaign, we will spend 31 days trying to raise enough funds to reach our first goal of $50,000 and then strive to get as close to our $1.6M budget as possible. While $50,000 is our initial target, we hope to hit our 6 other stretch goals that will allow us to continue the animation process. Each step is vital in getting the film as beautiful, polished, and professional as we imagine it can be; whether that be through this campaign or as we partner with production companies and animation studios to close the gap.
It’s incredibly important that we remain transparent, so we created an outline below to show you exactly where your hard-earned money will go. We're hoping production will begin with Powerhouse Animation Studios in August 2021 and for the animation to be completed by October 2022.

 "When Black Boys Feel They Heal" - Keith F. Miller, Author of Pritty the novel & Executive Producer of Pritty: The Animation 
Today, few animated queer coming-of-age stories exist for black men. Pritty aims to fill this gap and expand a necessary conversation around what it means to be a black boy coming-of-age in America.
Pritty is a universal but unique story of one teenage boy’s journey through pain and trauma to transformative self-acceptance and healing. It purposely flips the typical narrative arc that audiences have come to expect from queer films where the boy gets bullied and either succumbs or survives. And, instead, pushes against what we’ve been conditioned to consider possible...arriving on the other side of healing, hope, and community.
This story was created in response to a startling, ever-present truth: boys and young men of color face innumerable obstacles that prevent them from living long, full, healthy, and productive, emotionally-rich lives. And more than anything these obstacles stand to block young men from feeling.
We believe there is a correlation between the limited range of queer black male representation on screen and the staggering number of suicide attempts amongst black male LGBTQ+ youth.
Unfortunately, most black queer coming-of-age films habitually reproduce traumas onscreen without visualizing futures beyond the “coming out” experience.
Pritty aims to address this disparity by showcasing black men in an unconventional light. Instead of watching black boys fight, belittle and harm one another; we get to watch them at play, figuring themselves out, making themselves vulnerable and healing in the process.
Visualizing a world where black boys get to express themselves without consequence models an alternative reality for queer black youth, which present-day narratives don’t even allow them to imagine.


We greatly appreciate any and all support towards this project - be it monetary or otherwise. We would love it if you could spread the word about our Kickstarter with your own community by sharing the link to our campaign.
You can also follow us on Instagram and Twitter @prittynotpretty to stay connected to the world of Pritty! Our Pritty universe includes this animated short film, but also goes beyond it to include Keith's forthcoming novel, a live-action feature film adaptation (soon to come), and so much more that we can't wait to show you!

 More Insight Into Some of Our Fundraising Perks: 
 We’re thrilled to offer you a selection of campaign-exclusive perks as a thank you for supporting Pritty: The Animation. 
$15 or more - Pritty Phone Wallpaper


$100 or more - Pritty Postcards
$250 or more - Pritty T-Shirt


$750 or more - Pritty Mug & Self-Care Basket
$1,000 or more - A Behind-The-Scenes Look Into Pritty
$2,500 or more - Q&A w/ Pritty Team & Special Guest
$5,000 or more - Pritty Coffee Table Book & Sweatshirt
$10,000 or more - EP Credit & Dramatic Reading of Pritty: the novel

Have a question about our campaign?
Email us at prittynotpretty@gmail.com.
campaign.risks:
Risks and challenges
Our producing team has been working on Pritty for over a year now. We believe that we are well-equipped to handle anything that comes our way - especially after we pivoted to animation during the start of the COVID-19 pandemic. However, our biggest challenge with the project is that animation is a new endeavor for many of us. This is why we are collaborating with our partners at Powerhouse Animation Studios. We are confident that Powerhouse will be able to manage the workflow of this film because we have already collaborated with them on the teaser animatic (which you can watch in our campaign video). We believe in Powerhouse's creative ability and we have already established a workflow and positive relationship with them. We don't anticipate any major challenges, but should the unexpected pop-up, we'll be sure to communicate any issues or delays with you right away.
Learn about accountability on Kickstarter

support.descp:
Gain access to a private live virtual Q&A with Director, Terrance Daye, EP, Keith, and Producers Jeremy Truong and Natalie Jasmine Harris. Moderated by an extra special guest! The Q&A will be held over Zoom and all donors who are not able to attend will receive a private link to its recording.

The coffee table book will feature art centered around the various themes that inspire Pritty: The Animation like re-defining Black masculinity, healing, and life in The Deep South.

updates.update_content:
Hey Everyone!
We'll be thanking you over and over until we can't anymore. Because of your donations, we have enough money to complete the 20-minute rough animatic, which gets us one giant step closer to animating, and to secure our voice-over cast for recording audio.
We just got our official quote from PowerHouse Animation -- *Terrance + Keith shimmy with joy*

updates.update_userinfo: That's a wrap on our Kickstarter for Pritty: The Animation!
updates.update_content:
There are times in our lives when we feel lonely and left to fend for ourselves. But since we launched this Kickstarter on March 1st, we were reminded by over 3,200 people that stories like Pritty: The Animation not only matter but they are needed for all of us to heal.
On behalf of the Pritty team and all the people we made this for, we will be able to do this because of and for you. Thank you for joining us on this journey and we look forward to sharing other updates with you along the way as we celebrate the path of Pritty: The Animation to the big screen.
To donate, you can send to (@LiveLovedProductions) on Venmo or you can click this link: .

This Kickstarter will officially come to an end in ~90minutes at 4:10 pm EST today. We’ve had such an incredible run so far! Any last RTs, shares, and donations would mean the world! Thank you, thank you, thank you!
-- Team Pritty

With just 24 hours to go on our Kickstarter, we're delighted to share that we've officially surpassed $100k towards Pritty: The Animation! Before the end of our campaign (4/1 at 4pm EST), we ask that you join us in making one final push in support of Pritty! 
If all 3,000 of you increased your pledge by $10 OR encouraged a friend to donate $10 in the next 24 hours, we would have enough money to secure our voiceover cast, fully animate our rough animatic, and add color to the animation for Pritty! So please keep spreading the word and shouting "Pritty: The Animation" from the rooftops!

We're almost to the finish line!
There are just 3 more days left of our Kickstarter campaign for Pritty! This whole journey has been an incredible blessing to us all! We honestly can't say thank you enough for showing up and supporting us this far! 
Please keep spreading the word and encouraging your loved ones to help us as we bring to life! Every dollar truly counts as we near the end of our campaign. Let's finish strong! April 1st, here we come!

We are so delighted that our Pritty family now has over 2,000 beautiful backers from all over the world! With just 7 days left of our Kickstarter campaign, we're working towards our stretch goal of $120k so that Pritty can truly finish strong! We hope that you can join us in continuing to spread the word before April 1st!
As our Director, Terrance Daye said in our last update: "Please continue to share and shout Pritty: The Animation from the rooftops. Because now more than ever, the world is listening!"

THANK YOU! 
Our hearts are so full! To celebrate us reaching our first goal of $50,000, below is a special note from our Director, Terrance Daye & Author of Pritty: The Novel, Keith F. Miller Jr.

There is no greater feeling in an up-and-coming artists’ career than to experience the volley of love and support that you have all shown over these past six days. My team and I couldn’t be happier or more proud to see a year’s worth of dreaming take us this far. But the journey isn’t over yet. Even greater heights await us and with 26 more days left in our campaign we are even more confident that we can reach our next stretch goal of 125K on the path to raising 1.6M for the full production budget. Please continue to share and shout n from the rooftops. Because now more than ever, the world is listening!

We have officially surpassed 1,000 backers on Kickstarter! 
Thank you so much for joining our Pritty family😊 We are so incredibly grateful for all of your support thus far & we can't wait to grow even more!
Much love!

WE ARE OVERJOYED! 
In just 24 hours after launching our campaign:
We raised over $17,000 (now over $23,000) 🤯
Kickstarter chose to highlight us as a #ProjectWeLove!
Our producer Natalie's tweet went viral! (Please retweet if you can!)

project_data.project_name: Pritty: The Animation

campaign.story:
*Update*: We have reached our initial goal of $40k for a rough cut of the movie thanks to you all! We are now looking to raise $120k as our new stretch goal to complete the entire, polished film. In addition, we are looking to gain 500 backers to spread awareness of our upcoming film. Thank you again for your love and support. 
- The Signing Animation team
The Story: Liftoff 
This story was born out of a desire to see accurate Deaf and Hard-of-Hearing (HoH) stories in animation.  We want to tell stories with Deaf/HoH main characters who have authentic, well-rounded experiences. 
Liftoff is a 9-minute 3D-animated short film which explores the mind of a Deaf dancer as she faces her fears about her big audition  Vivian is a born optimist and has loved dance ever since she was a little girl, but at 22, she's out on her own for the first time and finds her insecurities appearing the night before her audition for her dream ballet company. Will she conquer her nerves and show her true self as a performer, or will the anxiety swallow her whole?
While assembling our team, we found that Deaf/HoH talent was severely underrepresented in the animation industry, as were Deaf/HoH stories. Therefore, we created the animation studio and non-profit Signing Animation to uplift talent of all hearing types in integrated environments while creating Liftoff. We are creating meaningful representation for the Deaf/HoH community through our film, and affecting meaningful change to the animation industry for Deaf/HoH artists through our work at Signing Animation.
Support this Kickstarter because...
You want more stories about Deaf and Hard-of-Hearing (HoH) protagonists and underrepresented minorities.
You want to see American Sign Language in more animated films.
You believe that representation behind the camera matters.
You want to support a Deaf/HoH-majority studio with an integrated crew.
You want to support a studio that demonstrates diversity, inclusion, and positivity. 
You want to support Deaf/HoH artists in the animation industry.
In addition to an animation studio, Signing Animation is also a non-profit! We are a 501(c)(3) charity in the state of California. Your donations to our Kickstarter are tax-deductible and eligible for charity matching from your company. 
Characters
 Vivian 
Harmony
Art Process
Environments
This story takes place in the eclectic city of Chicago, a place special to our director, Carin. As Vivian's primary character color is pink, we took the red-gray-silver color palette of Chicago and looked at it through rose-colored glasses to have a better idea of how Vivian would view that setting. The strong blues and purples are used narratively throughout the story to indicate liberation and clarity.
The visual development crew channeled the apartments they had as 22-year-olds for the apartment that Vivian and Harmony share, including the hand decorations on the walls, the thrifted furniture, the preoccupation with string lights, and stickers absolutely everywhere. You can't see it in this picture, but one of the legs on the couch is missing, so they replaced it with a soup can. The crew frequently tell us that they wish they could live in Vivian and Harmony's apartment.
Our director spent several years living in Chicago (near the Kimball stop on the brown line, for those familiar with the El train.) She chose it because of its architectural variety and its status as a central artistic hub, home to the Joffrey Ballet, the Chicago Symphony, and the Chicago Art Institute, among many others.
Colorscript 
We move from a Dorothy-in-Kansas neutral palette at the beginning to a vivid rosy color scheme when Vivian is dreaming to show what it's like inside her head. As her tension increases, so does the temperature and intensity of the color script until it reaches a fever pitch on the stage. It was important to us to have a moment of visual quiet to give the audience time to process the story, so we have a moment of simplicity and emptiness, almost solitude, before the momentum of the story picks up again, and we break the feverishness of the colors with a cooling, powerful blue. When Vivian returns to the waking world, everything is just a little bit brighter, the way things are after a good night's sleep and a good decision reached.
Process Videos
The Atherton Ballet and its building was made up by the team to represent everything that's intimidating about established artistic forms: rigid traditions, rich and powerful sponsors, and a strong sense of obligation to conform. We wanted the building to look expensive, well-established, and a little scary, and we channeled various international opera and ballet houses to achieve the effect. 
PLAY

Animation Ambitions
We'll be attempting what many have not before: animating American Sign Language to  be dynamic and reflect the personality of the characters. American Sign Language is such a dynamic and exciting language to watch, and we want to reflect that spirit in our animation.
As ASL is a language consisting of rapid gestures, our development team was challenged to find a version of 3D animation which captured these nuances. We settled on a synthesis of 2D and 3D which eliminates motion blur and allows the language to move at an organic pace. Most crucially, we’ll have artists who use sign language executing sign language animation, making it understandable to native users of ASL. That’s the difference between false representation and authentic representation: legibility and authenticity.
Story Ambitions
There are many different ways to be Deaf/HoH, and we wanted to be able to represent many, not just one or two. That’s why Liftoff is the first of an animated anthology series featuring the dreams of Deaf/HoH people; cathartic dreams, funny dreams, nightmares, everything. The chosen story form of dreams is to allow an intimate look into the imaginations of these highly visual characters, and to let us use the infinite possibilities of the animation medium.
Expectations 
Works for Deaf/HoH audiences first
Features the holistic Deaf lived experience instead of focusing solely on the difficulties
Signing characters animated by signing artists
 (Slide template by SlidesCarnival)
Funding Ambitions
Your support enables us to create a magnificent film while paying our team of part-time crew, interpreters, and volunteers.
While our Kickstarter goal is set at $40k, here’s what your additional support can help us achieve:
 $40k raised (Reached!) enables us to create a rough cut of the movie with characters fully animated and environments fully modeled.
 $120k raised enables us to complete a high-quality short film with polish and post-production.
 $500k raised enables us to complete the film at a faster pace, pay our crew full-time, build out larger teams, and promote the film to larger audiences.
As you’ll read in the “Signing Animation: Who We Are” section of this page below, your support contributes toward building the careers of Deaf/HoH artists and making change in the animation industry through successful integrated environments.
(Slide template by SlidesCarnival)
Who We Are: Signing Animation 
Animation Studio and Nonprofit
Signing Animation began because representation starts in development. It's time for Deaf and Hard-of-Hearing (HoH) creators and artists to be recognized by the animation industry for the unique skill sets we bring. 
Storytelling is one of the most powerful vehicles for meaningful change, and as a proud, thriving culture with a rich history, the Deaf and Hard-of-Hearing community deserves to see themselves represented accurately, positively, and respectively in more onscreen stories.
Signing Animation's mission is threefold: 
Create meaningful Deaf/HoH animated stories with Deaf/HoH artists.
Contribute directly to a 200% increase in Deaf/HoH employment in US-based animation studios.
Affect positive societal change that supports the Deaf/HoH community through our films.   
(Slide template by SlidesCarnival)
Our mission began because Deaf/HoH applicants get this question at their interviews for studio work that hearing applicants don't: 
"How are we even supposed to communicate with you?" 
Because of long standing negative misconceptions about the ability of people who hear differently, the animation industry is largely without the tools to create and maintain Deaf/HoH-accessible workplaces. This places Deaf/HoH animation students, who graduate every year, without the means to earn an income from their degree.  
Signing Animation strives to provide these experiences to Deaf/HoH artists and crew while creating a film benefiting the Deaf/HoH community. In addition, Signing Animation identifies and connects artists and production team with opportunities in the animation industry.
(Slide template by Puress Online)
From the beginning we've required that our production team be 50% or more Deaf/HoH artists, and further, that each of those artists has access to opportunities in studios outside of ours. Part of our mission is to get studios to notice the extraordinary talents of our crew by: 
Holding roundtable events with major studios
Participating in career week at the National Technical Institute of the Deaf 
Consulting with recruiting departments
Promoting our artists for discussion panels
Posting job listings 
Every one of our artists has access to on-the-job growth opportunities, expert portfolio review, and peer critique, and we balance this by maintaining firm work-life boundaries and promoting physical and mental health. We watch movies together on Friday nights, and have recently begun taking dance classes together to avoid repetitive stress injuries, connect with our main character, and have some fun as a group.
Your contribution brings Vivian to the screen and keeps our mission alive! Come join the revolution and help us make a world where animation studios get excited when they see a Deaf/HoH applicant come through the door. Together we can affect meaningful change in a creative and lucrative industry while making beautiful stories!
Rewards
All of our rewards are made by our Signing Animation members or created in collaboration with Deaf/HoH-owned businesses.
Here’s a look into some of our rewards…

Custom-made Sticker
Express your love with stickers that say “I love you” in American Sign Language! We used Signing Animation brand colors so you can show your support.
Made in collaboration with Matt Daigle. Mattis the co-creator and artist for the hugely popular semi-autobiographical webcomic That Deaf Guy as well as In Deaf Culture and Extreme Interpreting. He lives with his family in Los Angeles.
Custom-made Key Chain
Show your support for Signing Animation, American Sign Language, and Deaf animation all in one kick-ass keychain!
Made in collaboration with D. Lopez. D. Lopez, @duppet_puppet on Instagram, is a Deaf LatinX artist who creates expressive multimedia art pieces about identity, advocacy, and inclusion.
Custom-made Luxurious Bath Bomb
Bathe in glory with this luxurious ballerina bath bomb. Designed to match with the color scheme of our film, the dusty baby pink bath bomb explodes into a mirage of blues, pinks and purple colors with aromas of vanilla and sandalwood.
Made in collaboration with Hotsy Totsy Haus. Hotsy Totsy Haus was founded by Christi Leonardi, a Deaf single mother, and has reached prominence as a luxury bath and body brand which also sells “unapologetically extra” lotions, oils, butters, and balms.
HANDMADE VEGAN NATURAL BATH BOMB. Ingredients for the bath bomb: Sodium Bicarbonate, Citric Acid, Organic Coconut Milk Powder, Grape Seed Oil, Medium Chain Triglycerides (Coconut Oil), Rose Clay, Essential Oil, Fragrance, Coco Betaine, Cosmetic Grade Colorant. 
Custom-made Signing Animation T-shirt
Wear your Signing Animation t-shirt with pride! The hand signs spell “S”, “A” and “I Love You” in American Sign Language.
Made in collaboration with Blue Wolf Branding. Blue Wolf Branding is part of a network of Deaf-owned businesses, including Heart Cruises and Heart Scooters, and provides top of the line branding and labeling on a huge array of products from t-shirts to journals.
Your sizes will be taken in a survey after/if the Kickstarter succeeds. 6.1 Oz. high quality, heavy weight fabric. 100% pre-shrunk cotton, open-end yarn cut to full specs and taped shoulder to shoulder, with two needle sleeve and bottom hem. 
Reward Details
All items made in collaboration are available as rewards and as add-ons.
These items are exclusive s and meant to be tokens of our appreciation for your generous support toward the film.
The cost of the rewards do not include the shipping costs, which will be added to your total at checkout. Shipping costs are waived for donations $500 and over.
In addition to an animation studio, Signing Animation is also a non-profit! We are a 501(c)(3) charity in the state of California. Your donations on Kickstarter are tax-deductible and eligible for charity matching from your company.
The People Behind the Film
This film is being created by a remarkable team. Here's a sneak peek into our talent...
CREATIVE TEAM SPOTLIGHT
Carin Powell - Director, Writer, Co-Founder of Signing Animation
Carin Powell is the writer and director of Liftoff, and co-founder of Signing Animation. Formerly a lead animator and fix team lead, Carin started Signing Animation with Nora Ng-Quinn in January 2020 as a way to combat the bias against Deaf/HoH talent in the animation industry. She has had single-sided deafness since early childhood, and has long been a proponent of Deaf Gain. Her mentors in animation include Eric Cera, Paul Naas, Peter Kelly, and Matt Majers. Through her work with Signing Animation she aims to demonstrate the singular talent of Deaf/HoH artists, the methods by which integrated teams can thrive, and the transformative power of storytelling.
Austin Balaich - Lead Rigger
Austin joined Signing Animation because he wanted to contribute to a film that represents authentic stories about Deaf people.  From his experience in the animation industry, stories about Deaf people are very underrepresented, and he's glad to be part of this group to help make the change!
Vivienne Crews - Storyboard Artist
Vivienne is a 24-year-old deaf visual artist with a lifelong passion for storytelling through her drawings and characters. Profoundly deaf at birth, she was born into a hearing family who recognized the importance of early language development and sought to provide her with a sign-language-rich environment as quickly as possible by studying and learning ASL. Her elementary education in Miami, Florida, was a mix of special deaf and mainstream classes until her early artistic talent was discovered, and she was enrolled in a fine arts magnet school at the age of 7; a sign language interpreter accompanied her to every class. Despite being the sole deaf student in all of her classes from 3rd grade all the way through to college graduation, her life’s true focus has always been art. She graduated in May 2019 from the School of Visual Arts in NYC with a Bachelor of Fine Arts degree in Computer Art, Computer Animation and Visual Effects. As far back as she can remember, she has been using my drawing skills to express her emotions and to communicate with the world, straddling the line between hearing and deaf cultures, never feeling completely a part of either. Facial expression, body position, and subtle movement are used to convey the details of her language – American Sign Language – and she relies heavily on these tools in her artwork, too. Storyboarding allows her to bring her characters and their stories to life, something she's dreamed of since she was very young. She is excited to be a part of the Signing Animation team and our mission to bring awareness of Deaf and hard-of-hearing talent to the industry forefront.
Natasha Hill - Internship Coordinator
Natasha is the only Deaf person from her hearing family. She's used American Sign Language her whole life. She was born and raised in Alaska, and loves mountains and Alaska's longest sunlight in the summer. She also loves sports and activities to keep her working out. She has a family cabin at Nancy Lake, and it's her favorite place to relax and enjoy some nature. She graduated from Rochester Institute of Technology last May 2020 with a Bachelor of Fine Arts and a minor in Communication. She's exploring her skills as an artist, including graphic design, video production, and photography. She loves to take videos and pictures of nature. She joined Signing Animation in June as an Internship Program Coordinator to help interns who build 3D models with feedback and help them with anything they need from us. She has been enjoying seeing our team growing with our varieties of skills.
Taylor Jones - Lead Modeler
Taylor Anne Jones is the Lead Modeler of Liftoff at Signing Animation. She graduated from Savannah College of Art and Design in June 2017 with a BFA and MA in Visual Effects and Animation, receiving multiple accolades for her work. Taylor specializes in 3D Modeling, Look Development, Character Design, Concept Art, Writing, and Quality Assurance for AAA video games. She hopes to share parts of her creative journey with others through developing strong characters and beautiful worlds. Her favorite joys in life are her family, cats, video games, films, and chocolate.
Søren Sparre - Animator
Soren is a Danish animator, currently living in Copenhagen. He recently finished his bachelor degree in Character Animation at The Animation Workshop school in Denmark. At moment he is working on a new feature project at Wilfilm studio in Copenhagen. His interest is in movies, TV series, computer games, and VR, and he is a frequent participant in TV-series projects in Copenhagen. He considers himself a creative actor with a great passion for facial expressions and body language. It has always been his dream to work with sign language in a movie. It is his goal to inspire others to dare to dream the impossible. He is searching for a new network outside Denmark, and he wants to meet other people who also want to work on sign language in 3D animation, in software programs such as Maya and Blender. He is openminded to meet new challenges and he is always happy to learn something new!

PRODUCTION TEAM SPOTLIGHT
 Nora Ng-Quinn - Head Producer, Co-founder of Signing Animation 
Nora Ng-Quinn is the producer of Liftoff and co-founder of Signing Animation. Following her education in film and theater from Cornell University and in acting at the Berkeley Repertory Theater, Nora became an accomplished producer and director during her time at Scary Cow Productions in San Francisco. Nora has dedicated herself to bringing stories from underrepresented groups to the screen, and is likewise committed to the creation of positive workplace cultures. She believes strongly that stories must involve the populations they depict in order to be respectful and truthful, and she is passionate about establishing the playbook for all animation studios to welcome Deaf/HoH talent.
Frank E. Abney III - Executive Producer
Frank began working in the entertainment world over a decade ago. He's been fortunate to work in games, TV, and film on a variety of projects. Frank wrote and directed the critically acclaimed short film Canvas, acquired and streamed by Netflix in 2020, based on his experiences with grief. Past projects include: Disney's "Frozen" and "Big Hero 6" (Academy Award winners for "Best Animated Feature"), DreamWorks Animation's "Kung Fu Panda 3", and "Boss Baby" (Academy Award Nominee for "Best Animated Feature"), Pixar's "Coco" (Academy Award winner for "Best Animated Feature"), and "Incredibles 2" (Academy Award Nominee for "Best Animated Feature").
Georgia Agbodjan - Producer
Georgia Agbodjan is a producer for Liftoff, and has been with Signing Animation since the earliest months. After her time at UC Davis studying economics, Georgia channeled her lifelong love of animation and film into a career as a video editor and digital content producer. She is dedicated to the cause of diverse storytelling with diverse crews, and joined Signing Animation to further its mission of representation. She has since learned much more about Deaf culture, gained a deeper appreciation for its diversity and nuances, and is now excited to see it brought forward in animation.
Zahna Simon - Producer, Inspired the Film
Producer Zahna Simon started her dance training with City Ballet School in San Francisco.  She expanded her dance background when she was accepted to San Francisco School of the Arts (SOTA) by training with Elvia Marta in Modern, Jazz, African, Ballet, Hip Hop and Choreography. Upon graduating from UCI with a BS in Chemistry and a BFA in Dance Performance, Zahna moved to San Diego to work full time at Vertex Pharmaceuticals and also performed with the Mesa College Dance Company, with CAC Repertory Dance Theatre (CACRDT.) and in Jean Isaac’s Trolley Dances 2013.  Zahna is now back in the Bay Area and is acting Assistant Director for both Urban Jazz Dance Company and the Bay Area International Deaf Dance Festival (BAIDDF) as well as helping to produce Signing Animation's short film Liftoff.
Antoine Hunter - Producer
Purple Fire Crow, also known as Antoine Hunter, is a producer, choreographer, and reference actor for Liftoff. Among his many accomplishments as an artist and Deaf advocate, Antoine has performed worldwide both as a solo artist and as the founder and artistic director of the Urban Jazz Dance Company in Berkeley. Having studied dance and film at the California Academy of the Arts, Antoine has used his talents for outreach and advocacy, partnering with foundations such as DeafHope, the California Association of the Deaf, and National Black Deaf Advocates, as well as local cultural centers such as the East Bay Center for the Performing Arts. He founded the Bay Area International Deaf Dance Festival in 2013, which unites Deaf talent around the globe.
Troy Kotsur - Producer
Troy Kotsur has been acting and directing for over 20 years. Deaf since birth, he was raised in Mesa, AZ. His career includes critically acclaimed performances in major films, an accomplished theater career which includes a lead role in the Broadway run of a Tony Award winning play, and numerous memorable roles on Television.Troy has garnered rave reviews for his leading role in the 2021 feature CODA, which was awarded Best Ensemble Cast at Sundance. Much of Troy’s success has stemmed from his highly respected career on stage. This includes a role the Tony Award winning run of Big River on Broadway, and the 2015 LA Drama Critics Circle Award nominee Spring Awakening. In television, Troy made headlines in 2019 for his acting role in The Mandalorian on Disney+ because along with acting, he choreographed an adapted form of sign language for the series. Other notable television roles include guest star appearances on Criminal Minds, Scrubs, CSI: NY, and a fan favorite recurring character on PAX’s Sue Thomas: FB-Eye 
Sam Sepah - Producer
Sam Sepah is a producer and onboarding specialist for Liftoff. Educated in 3D animation, social science, and HR management at RIT, Sam went on to be an HR consultant for such high-level companies as Google, the National Institute of Health, Sprint, and IBM. His specialty is in leadership programs and talent management, and he is contributing his wealth of experience in onboarding and team integration to Liftoff. Sam is a longtime employment rights advocate, and to date is the only Deaf HR professional working in a Fortune 500 company. He is committed to nurturing Deaf/HoH talent in animation and doing his part to ensure the success of new graduates entering the film industry.
Megan Swanson - Production Coordinator
Megan Swanson was born profoundly deaf,  and wears a cochlear implant. She is the Production Coordinator for Signing Animation's film Liftoff. Megan has been working to pave a path for everyone like herself who has a dream of being part of the film and television production industry. Megan started her production career in 2009 with Dreaming Tree Film's program “Fresh Films”, she then went on to perform at Walt Disney World Resort, finally making her dreams come true by moving to Los Angeles in 2015. Her credits include shows with Lifetime, Netflix, Panavision, and FX Network. In addition, Megan has appeared on the Netflix show “Nailed It” as a home baker (Season 1, Episode 4). Megan is passionate about community outreach and was crowned California Miss Amazing, and National Miss Amazing in 2017.  When not hard at work Megan enjoys exploring the stunning California coast and spending time with her dog Moe.
Thank You
Thank you so much for reading until the end. We appreciate you learning about our vision and our work. Thank you from all of us at Signing Animation!
Huge thanks to the Signing Animation individuals who worked so hard to put this Kickstarter together:
Carin Powell, Adam Buchbinder, Georgia Agbodjan, Nora Ng-Quinn, Megan Swanson, Caitlin Comstock, Chris Powell, Becks Edens, Heather Clarke, Kendra Cronk, Antoine Hunter, Zahna Simon, Sam Sepah, Troy Kotsur, Frank E. Abney III, Vivienne Crews, Austin Balaich, Ken Sparks, Cierra Wiley, Toj Mora, Kaela Mangiaracina. 
Promotional video song: "Roots" by Josh Leake
campaign.risks:
Risks and challenges
To ensure we are creating a film that is respectful to the Deaf/HoH community, we are intentionally asking for and listening to feedback on a frequent basis along our creation process. This may lengthen the time it takes to complete this film.
Learn about accountability on Kickstarter

updates.update_content:
The Kickstarter will end at 11:59pm PST tonight! Thank you for the kind words and love you all have shown us already.
We would be so grateful for any last shares, posts and donations made tonight. Help us reach 600 backers to show platforms like Netflix and Disney+ that people are genuinely interested in stories featuring Deaf culture made by Deaf/HoH artists. 
Thank you again for your love and support,

What an INCREDIBLE way to wake up!! We had to double-check the numbers just to be sure: 505 followers, and over 56K!!! To all our backers, your presence here sends a clear message: "we want to see this! We care about respectful representation! We want to make sure it's made by the community it shows!" That's the type of decisive statement which drives meaningful change industry-wide, and we couldn't have done it without you. Thank you so, so much!
With 15 hours left and our initial goals met, all that's left to do is to see how far we can get into funding for the next phase! We're nearing 60K, and that means when the time comes to fund post-production, we'll be halfway to the total amount already - absolutely amazing. As a final reminder, here are our goals and what we can do with them:

updates.update_userinfo: It all comes down to this!

updates.update_content:
We are so grateful to you all for helping us reach our initial funding goal of $40k! We were ecstatic to see our community validate Deaf/HoH stories as important. It was amazing to see so many people believe in our ability to create a film that will impact the Deaf/HoH community.
Last Thursday, the entire crew came together to toast to our backers and celebrate - everyone worked incredibly hard to reach this point, and it was wonderful to enjoy our Kickstarter success together before diving right back into the work we love.

Our artists have been working hard to make these beautiful drawings into three-dimensional figures, and thanks to our modeler Taylor Jones and rigger Austin Balaich, Vivian is now 3D! Taylor used our character designer's reference drawings to meticulously craft a base model, and Austin has been placing controls on it so that the animators can move Vivian around. She's still a 'scary gray ghost' at the moment (all base models come untextured, so they look a little like clay statues before we tell them what color and texture things like skin and hair should be,) but it won't be long before she's colorful!

campaign.story:
Hi, I'm Tom Brinton.
I'm creating a procedurally-generated pencil and paper dungeon that you can easily carry in the back pocket of your jeans. 

The basics:
Each book is unique, because:
Each page is randomly generated
Play wherever, whenever

What you get:
A 3x5" inch memo pad printed in Provo, UT. It has a thick front and back cover. Includes a matte black golf pencil that slides perfectly into the spiral binding, and a black and white d6 that you can carry along as well.
Sample pages (Subject to change)



How to play:
Gameplay is simple but entertaining: you roll a 6-sided die to determine how far you'll move each turn. Then pick a direction, draw a line, and interact with anything on that line, be it a monster (ouch!) some treasure (nice!) or a teleporter (cool!).
Customize your character, roll your way through each floor, and get items at the shops sprinkled throughout the game. There's even a page in the back to track stats like how many times you died -- so if you die, don't worry! It's all part of the adventure.

You can get a PDF of sample rules and level here

Testing a prototype

How I'm making it:
I am using software called Drawbot that allows me to code a level generator in Python. This generates PDFs which I will send to a local printer to get the notebooks made. This means that each game pad is different - each one has random level layouts and different shops. So if you get more than one game pad, you'll have different levels to play!

Levels are generated with Python code using Drawbot


Why I'm making it:
I feel compelled to cut games down to their bones and to see what makes them tick. In that spirit, I'm trying to strip this genre down to its simplest form: 1 player, simple mechanics, no story-telling, just you, a die and pencil, and a series of simple decisions in the face of randomness. 

As a product designer, I have been thinking for a long time about the concept of "paper apps". In fact I've created one already. Sometimes you want to do something during a dull moment, but don't want to get sucked into your phone screen. Paper apps fill that gap with discrete, screen-free experiences that respect your time and attention. Eventually I plan on creating a whole Paper App Library (PAL) that will include all sorts of little notebook "apps", including games and utilities.

About me:
I've been creating games since I first learned to program in QBASIC as a kid. I have published several video games and even published a tabletop game on Kickstarter back in 2013. I am interested in game design, graphic design, and product design. 
Paper Apps is a joint effort of my video game company, Beep Yeah!, and the design company I run with my wife, Gladden.
campaign.risks:
Risks and challenges
The main risk involves getting printed and shipped. However, I have made "paper apps" like this before and I have a process in place. COVID restrictions may slow things down, but only by a week or two. I have factored all of this into the delivery times.
Learn about accountability on Kickstarter

Hello everyone,

I've had many people reach out about purchasing more copies of Paper Apps™ DUNGEON. I have opened up orders for a second print run.

updates.update_userinfo: Be on the lookout: notebooks are arriving!
updates.update_content:
Hi everyone,
I've heard from a few people today that their books have arrived! I'd love to see photos of your books, tweet them at me @brintown on Twitter, or tag us @gladden.design on Instagram!
Also, the complete rulebook is now available on our website. It's 6 pages long and should answer anything you need to know about playing Paper Apps™ DUNGEON.

Hi everyone!
Notebooks are printed and have begun to ship out all around the world. Depending on your distance from Utah, it could take anywhere from a few days to a few weeks, so be patient--they are coming!

Hi everyone!
Today I drove to Alexander's, my print partner here in Utah. They showed me some sample prints and everything is looking amazing, just how I imagined it.

Hi there everyone!
Sorry for the quiet couple of weeks. My second kid was born on Feb 28th and she’s been my top priority!
In the few free moments here and there, I have finished the dungeon generation code with a lot of help from my friend Alex Morris.

Hey everyone!
I have found a print shop here in Utah that is ready to print and ship all 14,000 games! :0 Because of that, it's time for Backer Surveys. If you haven't seen yours yet, check your inbox (or maybe even your spam folder!)
Once all the surveys are filled out, I can order dice and pencils and move forward with printing notebooks, stuffing envelopes, and shipping them to your doorstep!!

updates.update_userinfo: An amazing ride so far! THANK YOU!
updates.update_content:
Well, we made it. I'm still in a bit of shock--this project was over 10000% funded thanks to all of you.
I want to keep you all in the loop, so here's a list of a few things I am working on now:
Creating sample PDFs for our print partners so we can start getting production-ready.
Putting together the backer survey. This will be done via Kickstarter, and will ask your address and other info relevant to your pledge.

Hi there, everyone!

A few important notes before this thing ends in 2 DAYS :

- My goal from the beginning has been to keep this game and Kickstarter as simple as possible. For that reason, I have decided that pledging will end when the campaign ends. I will use Kickstarter's built-in survey tool to get addresses and let you choose the number of pencils and dice you want. Locking the number of books, pencils, and dice down will let me get started on the production side of things faster.
